text: Always lock your doors and windows—even when you’re at home. Burglars often target unlocked entrances.
When walking at night, stay on well-lit streets and avoid shortcuts through alleys or empty parking lots.
Keep a 3–4 car-length distance when driving to allow time for sudden stops, especially in wet or icy conditions.
In hot weather, carry a reusable water bottle and check on elderly or vulnerable neighbors who may overheat.
If you see suspicious activity, note descriptions (clothing, vehicle license plate) and report it to police immediately.
Never leave valuables visible in your car. Lock them in your trunk or take them with you.
Memorize or save emergency numbers (e.g., 911, Poison Control at 1-800-222-1222) in your phone’s favorites.
During winter, treat sidewalks with salt or sand to prevent slips and falls. Wear footwear with good traction.
If you’re going on a long trip, tell a trusted friend your itinerary and check in by phone when you arrive safely.
Keep a small first-aid kit in your car or backpack. Include bandages, antiseptic wipes, and basic medications.
